August 18 at 8:30 AM ·

Minuteman Technical Institute is accepting student registrations through September for the 2020-21 school year at minutemanti.org.

Ninth graders: Are you sporting your Minuteman swag?!

Mr. Chiariello, the assistant principal of admissions, has been hitting the streets to deliver Minuteman High School shirts, sunglasses, and more to our newest students. Kevin Mukherjee of Arlington even stopped by the school with his family to take some photos!!

“I drove hundreds of miles, met dozens of families, and did more U-turns than I could count, but it was all worth it to welcome our incoming ninth graders to the Minuteman family,” Mr. Chiariello said. “I can’t wait for our students to get the school year started at Minuteman, where you’ll get to explore your passion, discover your purpose, and experience joy in learning.”

Our first day of school is Sept. 16. For more information on our hybrid learning model, visit minuteman.org/fall2020.

Charles Lovett, 18, a horticulture student from #Arlington, is an #EssentialWorker during the COVID-19 crisis, working at Newton Cemetery, an accredited arboretum. He's worked there while gaining course credit since last year.

Charles works in the greenhouse as well as on the grounds. In the greenhouse, he assists the head grower with planting, transplanting, fertilizing, and irrigation. On the grounds, he preps and plants garden beds, performs tree and shrub plant healthcare, and turf maintenance.

Charles is part of Minuteman's Farmers for America Club, Community Service Club, and has traveled to Puerto Rico and New Orleans with the school to help with rebuilding efforts following natural disasters.

Lily Mela, a sophomore health assisting student from Lexington, is working on the front lines of the coronavirus crisis at the Brookhaven assisted living facility in Lexington.

She started working there just a few weeks before the pandemic began. “I wanted to protect the elders. I wasn’t concerned for my safety,” she said. “I had to stop thinking about the dangers because it wasn’t worth it.”

Mela, 16, said she serves meals to the residents – none of whom can leave their quarters due to social distancing measures – and was provided one face mask to be re-used daily. Some of the residents have dementia and leave their rooms because of memory issues.

After each shift, Mela returns home and immediately washes her clothes and takes a shower.

“There’s some small concern, but we’re not freaking out over it,” said her father, Robert Mela. “It’s useful, meaningful work.”

“It’s solidified my urge to work in healthcare, Lily Mela said. “It’s not something that’s meant for everyone, but it’s important work to do.” #BeEssential #MinutemanHS #EssentialWorkers

April 30 at 12:39 PM · Lexington, MA ·

Spec & Images at: https://www.ybc.com/minuteman-high-school/

The timber bridge design at Minuteman High School in Lexington, MA commemorates a local revolutionary war icon, the Old North Bridge. It reflects simplicity of colonial era architecture, clean lines and hearty structural details. It also provided a competitively priced and low-impact alternative to the originally considered culverts. Each of the five bridges are customized to embrace the wetlands’ curves & skews, delivering fluid site circulation & uniting the state-of-the-art vocational high school campus. AASHTO HS-20 load capacity supports traffic from commuters, school buses, & emergency vehicles. As students get a grip on their career path, our anti-skid aggregate surfaced timber deck gives traction to their physical path. The heavy wood grain saturated by the oil coatings pops with a rich tint staying true to the natural warmth of timber and remaining beautiful for future generations at Minuteman High School. #kaestleboosassociates
